ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Arabic writing and reading skills
I learned about different arab literary writers and about arabic poetry
In this class, we presented on various authors and also read and discussed works by them.
I learned about a broad range of modern Arabic literature.

This course furthered my knowledge of Arabic, particularly as regards vocabulary, but additionally, I learned a great deal about Arabic literary movements, postcolonial Arabic literature, and received a comprehensive introduction to modern Arabic poetry.
Learning how to critically read and write about novels and short stories in Arabic.
I learned about Arab writers and literature from different countries. I improved my reading and writing skills in Arabic.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: strengths: we learned a lot about different arab writers and read different styles of stories and work which was pretty interesting

I appreciated learning about various authors and their work. At the same time, I do not believe that I was provided with the opportunity to improve my Arabic skills. I think that for non-native speakers, reading about 60 pages a week is challenging. Moreover, I wish that we had discussed what we had read in class to learn more about different themes and writing styles. I also believe that it's important to encourage non-native speakers to talk in Arabic and more importantly, make mistakes without fearing judgement, which this class did not do all that successfully.

The strengths are that the readings were very interesting and I enjoyed writing all of our papers. The weaknesses are that the classes often felt repetitive. I would have liked to have done more diverse activities in class. I would have liked to have discussed the reading more in class with the professor and other students.

The course was tailored to the needs of students. Also, all of the texts chosen were very different and unique and allowed for good discussion. At first, the workload was quite high, but Ustath Aziz is great and corrected it accordingly.
I would say to include more poetry and really focus on literature rather than allowing students to present about current issues or politics.

This course could have been more engaging at times, because the structure was repetitive and some of the work felt like busy work. It was very good of the prof to shorten the lengths of the papers, but the weekly presentations became repetitive and it would have been nice to have different ways to engage in discussion.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I liked doing the student presentations online. Also, professor Aziz was able to use different online tools such as kahoot, the color wheel, and vocab website which allowed us to better engage in an online format
I enjoyed the weekly presentations. I think we could have spent more time in class analyzing our readings.
I appreciated the use of written questions to structure the discussion. Especially when online, the added structure helped a lot.
Shortening the papers was good and very much needed. However engagement was low because discussion was minimized and lecturing emphasized.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes I would if you want to continue working on your arabic reading and speaking
I would recommend this to someone as an opportunity to read more Arabic literature.
Certainly, this is an excellent course for those with an advanced knowledge of arabic.
Yes! This is a great upper level Arabic class, especially if you're interested in literature.
Not really, I like the prof as a person but the course was not very engaging.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: it was a virtual small discussion section mode of learning
Virtual seminar
N/A
